div.note: While awaiting the hour to go to church and celebrate the Mass, Cardinal Federigo was reading a book—his usual habit in his spare time—when the chaplain came in with an odd look on his face.
“A strange visitor, Your Grace, truly strange!”
“Who is it?” asked the Cardinal.
“None other than ***,” answered the chaplain, emphasizing each syllable as he uttered the name (which I cannot share with my readers), adding, “He’s outside.
In person. And he is requesting nothing less than an audience with Your Grace.”
“He is?” said the Cardinal, his face suddenly animated. He closed his book and stood up from his chair. “Show him in!
Show him in at once!” “But,” replied the chaplain without moving, “Your Grace should know who he is: He’s a criminal, the notorious…”
“And should a bishop not feel blessed that a man like him suddenly wants an audience?”
“But,” insisted the chaplain, “we’re never allowed to talk about certain matters, because Your Grace says it’s nothing but gossip. But when the situation arises, I think it’s my duty.
After all, zealousness will earn you enemies, Your Grace, and we know for a fact that more than one criminal has threatened that sooner or later—”
“And have they?” interrupted the Cardinal.
“I’m saying he’s a murderer, an outlaw, who’s in league with the meanest outlaws a man who might have been sent—”
“This is a strange form of protocol,” Federigo interrupted again with a smile. “Are the soldiers urging their general to be afraid?”
Then, turning serious and pensive, he continued, “San Carlo would never have hesitated to receive such a man: He would have gone to him himself!
Show him in at once; he’s waited too long as it is.”
The chaplain left, muttering, “It’s hopeless: These saints are all so stubborn!”

As he opened the door and returned to the room where the Nameless One and others were gathered, he saw the priests huddled to one side of the room, whispering and casting furtive glances at the visitor, who was standing alone on the other side of the room.

The chaplain headed toward the man, sizing him up furtively, and wondering what kind of arsenal was concealed beneath his coat. And whether, before showing him in, he really should have asked…but he couldn’t bring himself to do it.
He went up to him and said, “His Grace awaits your Lordship.
Please follow me.”

He led him through the small crowd, which immediately parted to let them pass, casting glances to the right and to the left as if to say, “What do you expect? Don’t you realize that Federigo always does everything his own way?”

The moment the Nameless One entered the room, Federigo went over to him with an eager and serene face, arms open wide, as he would for a welcome guest. He then gestured for the chamberlain to leave, which he did.
The two men stood there for a few moments without speaking, each hesitating for different reasons.

The Nameless One had been driven there by an inexplicable urge rather than a specific purpose. He was torn between two opposing passions: a vague longing to be relieved of his inner torment, and a feeling of shame and aggravation to have come before the Cardinal like a penitent, subdued and abject, to confess his guilt and beg forgiveness from another man. He couldn’t find or almost search for the right words to say.

Still, as he raised his eyes to the man before him, he was pierced by a feeling of veneration both powerful and soothing that, while building his trust, lowered his contempt, and, without directly attacking his pride, still crushed it, and, I would say, forced him into silence.
Federigo’s presence was, in fact, the kind that conveys superiority yet inspires love.

He carried himself in a manner that was both natural and almost unconsciously majestic, neither stooped nor wasted by age. His eyes were grave and lively, his forehead serene and pensive. Despite his white hair and pallor—the marks of a life of abstinence, meditation, and toil—he had a kind of virginal glow. From his facial features one could see that, in his youth, he must have been what is properly considered handsome. But the habit of solemn and benevolent thought, the inner peace of a long life, the love of humanity, and the constant joy of an ineffable hope, had replaced it with what I would almost call the beauty of old age, highlighted by the magnificent simplicity of his purple cassock.

For a few moments, the Cardinal trained on the Nameless One his penetrating gaze, long experienced in deciphering thoughts from appearances. He sensed that beneath the man’s dark and troubled face there was something close to the hope he himself had felt at the announcement of this visit. “Oh!” he said enthusiastically, “This is such a precious visit! And I am so grateful to you for the good decision to undertake it, although I am somewhat at fault.”
“At fault!” exclaimed the lord, amazed but also comforted by the Cardinal’s words and his manner, and relieved that the Cardinal had broken the ice.
“Yes, of course I’m at fault,” continued the other, “for I made you come to me, when I should have been the one to come to you long ago.”
“You? To me?
Don’t you know who I am?
Are you sure you heard my name correctly?”
“My joy must be showing on my face! Do you think I would feel this way at the announcement—at the sight—of a stranger?

You are the one who makes me feel this; you, as I said, whom I should have sought; you, whom I have so loved and grieved for, whom I have so prayed for; you, of my children, all of whom I dearly love, the one I should have most wanted to welcome and embrace, if I had believed I could hope for it.
But God alone can perform miracles. He alone can make up for the weakness and sloth of his poor servants.”
The Nameless One stood there in silence, dumbstruck and overcome with emotion.
“What’s wrong?” Federigo continued, even more affectionately. “You are here to bring me good news. Why are you so reluctant to tell me?”
“Good news? Me?
The fires of hell are burning in my heart! I should have good news for you?
Tell me, please, if you can, what good news you could expect from a man like me?”
“That God has touched your heart, and wants to make you one of His own,” replied the Cardinal calmly.
“God!
God! God!
If only I could see him! If only I could hear him!
Where is this God?”
“You are asking me? You?
Who is closer to Him than you?

Don’t you feel Him in your heart, weighing on you, disturbing you, never leaving you a moment’s peace? Don’t you feel Him drawing you in, holding before you the hope, in His tranquility and joy, for a joy that will be even more complete and immense the moment you recognize Him, confess your sins, and pray to Him?”
“Of course I do! Something is weighing on me, eating at me!
But is it God?
If this God exists, if He is who they say He is, what would God want with me?”
These words were uttered with a pang of despair, but Federigo replied in a voice that was solemn yet serene. “What would God want with you? With you?
He can make you into an instrument of His power and goodness! He can attain a glory through you that no one else could give Him.

Although many in the world have long condemned you, and thousands upon thousands detest your actions”—for a moment the Nameless One was startled, astonished to hear himself criticized so openly, and even more astonished to feel relieved rather than indignant—“and what glory,” Federigo continued, “would they bring to God?

Theirs are the voices of fear, voices of self-interest, calling out, perhaps, for justice, but a type of justice too easy, too obvious! And some of these voices, unfortunately, may envy your wretched power, your—until now—deplorable self-assurance.
But if you yourself stand up to condemn the life you have led, to accuse yourself, well then, there will be glory to God!
And you ask what use God may have for you?

Who am I, a poor mortal, to tell you how you can benefit the Lord? What can He do with your impetuous will, your unshakable constancy, after He has reawakened your will and inflamed it with love, hope, and repentance?
Who are you, poor mortal, to think the evil you plot and commit is greater than God’s ability to make you desire and strive for the good?
You ask what God can do with you?
He can forgive you! Save you! Redeem you!
Are these things not magnificent and worthy of him?

Just think! If I—weak, miserable, though proud man that I be—am so consumed by your health now that I would gladly sacrifice the few days I have left on this earth (as God is my witness), then imagine the greatness of His love, He who infuses my own imperfect but ardent love.
Imagine how He loves and wants you, He who commands and inspires in me an all-consuming love for you.”
As these words left his lips, his face, his expression, and his every gesture radiated with their meaning.

His listener’s face in turn changed from upset and agitated to stunned and intent, and then settled into a deeper calm. Eyes that had not shed a tear since childhood welled up. And when the Cardinal’s speech ended, the Nameless One gave his final and most unguarded response: He covered his face with his hands and began to sob uncontrollably.

“God is good, God is great!” exclaimed Federigo, raising his eyes and his hands to the heavens, “What have I ever done, I, your worthless servant, your sleeping shepherd, to deserve an invitation to this banquet of grace, to witness this joyful miracle?”
As he spoke, he reached out for the hand of the Nameless One.
“No!” cried the latter. “No! Away from me, away! Do not defile your innocent and generous hand.
You do not know the things that my hand has done.”

“Allow me,” said Federigo, taking it firmly but affectionately, “allow me to grasp this hand that will right so many wrongs, spread so much good, soothe so many of the afflicted, and reach out—unarmed, peaceful, and humble—to so many enemies.”
“This is too much!” sobbed the Nameless One.
“Leave me, Your Grace. Good Federigo, leave me be.
A crowd of people is waiting for you. All good people, all innocent, many of whom have come from far away to see or hear you just this once. And yet you keep them waiting…to be with me!”
“Let us leave the ninety-nine sheep,” replied the Cardinal, “they are safe on the mountain. Now I wish to spend some time with the one that went astray.
Those other souls may be even happier than if they had seen this poor bishop.
Perhaps God, who has performed the miracle of mercy in you, is filling them at this very moment with a joy that they do not yet understand.

They may already be with us without realizing it. Perhaps the Holy Spirit has instilled in their hearts a vague yearning to give love, a prayer for you, a prayer of thanksgiving of which you are the unknown recipient.”

As he spoke, he embraced the Nameless One, who, after trying to resist and pull away for a moment, surrendered, as if overcome by that impulse of love. He embraced the Cardinal in turn, and let his trembling, altered face fall to the other man’s shoulder.

His burning tears landed on the untainted purple tunic of Federigo, whose guiltless hands affectionately clasped his fingers and patted a coat accustomed to bearing the weapons of violence and treachery.
The Nameless One slipped out of the embrace, covered his eyes with one hand, and, turning his face upward, exclaimed, “God truly is great!

God truly is good! Now I know myself; I understand who I am. My sins stand before me, and I am filled with self-loathing. And yet…and yet I feel refreshed by a joy…yes, a joy that I have never before felt in my whole horrible life!”

“God is giving you a taste of that joy to draw you into his service,” Federigo said, “to give you a new life that you will enter into resolutely, a new life in which you will have so much to undo, to repair, to regret!”
“I am such a wretch!” exclaimed the nobleman. “There are so many, so many things that I can only regret!
But there is one deed, at least, that I have only just begun, that, if nothing else, I can interrupt, undo, and repair.”

Federigo listened attentively. In even stronger words of loathing than I have used, the Nameless One briefly described the outrages Lucia had suffered, how the poor girl’s terrors, anguish, and pleas had sent him into a frenzy, and how she was still at the castle…
“We have no time to waste!” exclaimed Federigo, gasping with piety and concern.
“You are blessed!
This is a token of God’s forgiveness! He is allowing you to become an instrument of salvation for the very person you had sought to ruin.
May God bless you!
Indeed, He already has!
Do you know where this poor tormented soul is from?”
He gave the name of Lucia’s village.
“That’s not far from here,” said the Cardinal, “praise God; and perhaps…” As he spoke, he ran to a side table and shook a bell.

In came the chaplain, with a worried look on his face. He cast a glance at the Nameless One and noticed his altered expression and reddened eyes. Then, he looked at the Cardinal, in whom he sensed a solemn happiness and impatient haste beneath his unflappable exterior. The chaplain stood there, slack-jawed and astonished, until the Cardinal brought him back to earth, asking whether the pastor of *** was present among the priests gathered outside.
“He is, Your Grace,” replied the chaplain.
“Send him in at once,” said Federigo, “together with the local priest.”
The chaplain left and returned to the room where the priests were assembled. All eyes turned to him.

With his mouth still agape, his face still painted with astonishment, he waved his hands in the air, calling, “Gentlemen! Gentlemen! Haec mutatio dexterae Excelsi—Here is the right hand of the Most High!”
And he stood there for a moment, saying nothing more.
Then, resuming his official tone and voice, he added, “His Most Illustrious and Reverend Eminence wishes to see the local pastor as well as the parish priest of ***.”
The first man came forward at once; at the same time, a lone “Me?” mumbled and tinged with disbelief, emerged from the crowd.
“Are you not the pastor of ***?” asked the chaplain.
“One and the same, but…”
“His Most Illustrious and Reverend Archbishop wishes to see you.”
“Me?” that voice repeated, the monosyllable clearly asking, “What’s this got to do with me?”
But this time, emerged the man together with the voice: Don Abbondio in person, with a hesitant step and a face both stunned and disgruntled.
The chaplain gestured to him, as if to say, “Come along, what’s taking you so long?” then, leading the way, he went to the door, opened it, and ushered in the two priests.
The Cardinal let go of the Nameless One’s hand, having concluded their arrangements. He stepped away and gestured to the local priest to approach.

He told him the story briefly, and asked the priest whether he couldn’t immediately find a good matron to travel in a sedan chair to the castle to fetch Lucia: a woman with a good heart and a good head, who would know how to behave on such an unusual mission—the most appropriate manners to adopt, and how to find the most suitable words, to hearten and calm the poor girl for whom, after so much distress and turmoil, being released might prove even more upsetting.
After giving it a moment’s thought, the priest said he had just the right person, and left.
With another gesture the Cardinal summoned the chaplain, whom he ordered to arrange immediately for the sedan chair and chairmen, and to have two mules saddled.
Once the chaplain had left, the Cardinal turned to Don Abbondio.

The priest was already standing near him, in order to keep his distance from the nobleman on the other side of the room. He cast a furtive glance at first one man, then the other, wondering what all the fuss was about. He then made a slight bow to the Cardinal, saying, “I have been informed that Your Grace wishes to see me, but I believe there has been a mistake.”
“No, there hasn’t,” replied Federigo. “I have some good news for you, as well as a gratifying and most pleasant errand.

One of your parishioners, Lucia Mondella, whom you must have thought was lost for good, has been found. She’s near here, in the home of this dear friend of mine. I want you to go with him now; bring with you the woman that the local priest has gone to find. That is, you are to go to fetch your parishioner and accompany her back here.”

It was all Don Abbondio could do to hide how annoyed, irritated, and bitter this proposal—this order—had made him. With no time to compose his face or wipe away the frown that had already formed on it, he hid his feelings by bowing his head in a gesture of obedience.
He then raised his head and made a deep bow to the Nameless One, with a pitiful look as if to say: “I am in your hands, have mercy on me: Parcere subjectis—spare the defeated!”
The Cardinal asked him whether Lucia had any relatives.
“If you mean close relatives with whom she lives or has lived, she only has her mother,” replied Don Abbondio.
“And is she home?”
“Yes, Your Grace.”

“Considering,” Federigo continued, “that the poor girl cannot go straight home, I’m sure she would be overjoyed to see her mother immediately. So, if the local priest is not back before I go to church, please tell him to order a cart or a saddle horse and send a sensible man to look for the mother and bring her here.”
“And if I were to go?” asked Don Abbondio.
“No, no. Not you. I’ve already given you something else to do,” replied the Cardinal.
“I meant,” pursued Don Abbondio, “to prepare her poor mother.
She’s a very sensitive woman, and it would be best for her to be informed by someone who knows her, and knows how to handle her, in order to avoid doing more harm than good.”
“Which is why I’m asking you to tell the local priest who would be the right person for the job. You are needed elsewhere,” replied the Cardinal.

And he wanted to add, “After what the poor girl has gone through, hours and hours of anguish in that castle, not knowing what further horrors lie before her, she needs to see a familiar face, someone she trusts.”
But he did not want to be so blunt in the presence of the Nameless One.

It did seem odd to the Cardinal, however, that Don Abbondio had not already come to the same conclusion as himself. His alternative proposal and insistence seemed so inappropriate that he suspected something behind them.
He studied the priest’s face and could easily perceive the man’s fear of traveling with someone as intimidating as the Nameless One and entering his castle even for a few minutes.

Wanting to dispel that shadow of cowardice, but not wanting to pull the priest to one side and whisper to him in private while his new friend looked on, the Cardinal thought it best to do what he would have done anyway: speak directly to the Nameless One and hope that the man’s replies would make Don Abbondio realize that he was no longer to be feared.

So, with that spontaneous familiarity that characterizes both a strong new friend and an old intimate, the Cardinal went over to the Nameless One and said, “Don’t go thinking that we’re done for today.
You will come back, right? In the company of this good priest?”
“Will I be back?” replied the Nameless One. “Even if you rejected me, I would still remain stubbornly at your door, like a beggar.
I need to speak with you! I need to hear you, to see you! I need you!”
Federigo took his hand, saying, “So you won’t mind staying for dinner with us.
I’ll be waiting here for you.
In the meantime, I am going to pray, and offer up thanks with my people, while you go to gather the first fruits of divine mercy.”

Hearing this exchange, Don Abbondio was like a scared child watching a man safely patting his big, growling hound and hearing him say that the animal, with its bloodshot eyes and reputation for biting and terror, is a nice doggy, good boy, good boy. The child looks at the master and neither agrees nor disagrees with him. But he looks at the dog, and doesn’t dare go near, for fear that the pooch will bare its teeth, maybe even take a bite out of him. At the same time, he doesn’t dare retreat, in case people notice. But in his heart, he says, “If only I were home!”
As the Cardinal prepared to leave, still holding the Nameless One’s hand, he noticed the look still on the face of the poor priest, who hung back, mortified, unhappy, and frowning despite himself.

Thinking that maybe he was unhappy because he felt left in a corner and ignored, especially compared to the warm welcome accorded to a violent criminal, the Cardinal stopped for a second, and, turning to him with a loving smile, said, “Reverend Father, you are always with me in the house of the Lord, but this man, ‘He was lost and now he is found.’ ”
“I couldn’t be happier!” said Don Abbondio, bowing with equal reverence to both men.

At that, the Archbishop pushed gently on the door. Two footmen manning the other side of the door immediately opened it, and the unusual pair appeared before the curious eyes of the assembled clergy, who witnessed two faces, each flush with different but equally profound emotions: a grateful tenderness and humble joy in the venerable Federigo, while in the Nameless One, a confusion tempered by relief, and a new shame, a compunction, which did not entirely conceal the vigor of his savage and wrathful nature.
More than one observer would later remark how they were reminded of the verses from the book of Isaiah: “The wolf and the lamb shall feed together, and the lion shall eat straw like the ox” (65:25).
They were followed by Don Abbondio, whom no one even noticed.

When they had reached the middle of the room, the Cardinal’s chamberlain entered from the courtyard to report that he had carried out the chaplain’s instructions: The sedan chair and two mules were ready, waiting only for the woman who would comfort Lucia.

The Cardinal told his chamberlain to instruct the local priest the moment he arrived with the woman, to speak with Don Abbondio, who was leading the expedition together with the Nameless One. Before bidding farewell, he clasped the nobleman’s hand one last time and repeated, “I’ll be waiting for you.”
He turned to salute Don Abbondio and headed toward the church.
The clergy followed behind, half in a cluster and half in an orderly procession. The two traveling companions were left alone in the room.

The Nameless One was absorbed in thought, impatient for the moment when he could free his Lucia from her pain and imprisonment. Now she was his, in a very different sense than the day before. His face expressed an intense agitation, which to Don Abbondio’s suspicious eyes could have easily appeared to be something worse.

He looked at the nobleman out of the corner of his eye and would have liked to start up a friendly conversation, but, “What should I say to him?” he thought. “Should I repeat, ‘I couldn’t be happier’? Happy about what?
That, after a lifetime of doing the devil’s work, you’ve finally decided to become an honest man like everyone else?
Some compliment!…No matter how I put it, that’s all my congratulations will end up meaning.
And how do I know he really has suddenly turned into an honest man, out of the blue!
Plenty of people put on an act in this world, and for plenty of reasons!
How am I supposed to know what’s true?
Meanwhile, I have to accompany him! To that castle!
What a mess! What a mess!
If only someone had warned me this morning!

If I do make it out of this alive, I’ll give an earful to that Perpetua, who forced me to travel so far from my parish for no good reason, saying that all the priests, near and far, were coming here, and I shouldn’t be left out. She went on and on, to get me to embark on this wretched business!
Poor me!
Well, I’d still better think of something to say to him.”

After turning it over in his mind again and again, he figured he could try saying, “I hardly expected the good fortune of finding myself in such distinguished company.” He was about to open his mouth when in came the chamberlain with the local priest, who informed them that the woman was waiting in the sedan chair, then turned to Don Abbondio to hear the Cardinal’s additional instructions.

Don Abbondio delivered them as best he could in his confused state of mind, after which he approached the chamberlain, saying, “At least give me a tame animal because I’m not much of a horseman, to tell you the truth.”
“You needn’t worry,” the man replied, suppressing a chuckle. “The mule belongs to the secretary, a man of letters.”
“That will have to do,” replied Don Abbondio, while thinking, “God help us.”
Hearing that everything was ready, the Nameless One headed for the door quickly, but then he remembered Don Abbondio, who was lagging behind.

He stopped to wait for him, and when the priest arrived in a flurry, almost apologetically, he bowed with a courteous and humble gesture, allowing him to go first. This helped to calm the poor priest’s nerves.

But what he saw the moment he stepped into the courtyard ruined that brief consolation. The Nameless One went to the corner where he had left his carbine, grabbed it by the barrel with one hand and by the strap with the other, and with a brisk, well-practiced motion, slung it over his shoulder. “Oh, no! Oh, no!” thought Don Abbondio. “What does he mean to do with that contraption?
What kind of sacrifice, of self-mortification, is this for a recent convert?
What if something makes him lose his temper?
Oh, what manner of mission is this?”

If the nobleman had any inkling of what was going through his companion’s head, there’s no knowing what he would have done to reassure him. But he was thousands of miles away from suspecting anything, and Don Abbondio was careful to avoid any gesture that might have clearly signified, “I don’t trust you.”
When they got to the road, they found two mules saddled up. The Nameless One mounted the one presented to him by a groom.
“You’re sure it’s not skittish?” Don Abbondio asked the chamberlain, as he set back on the ground the foot he had just lifted up to the stirrup of his mule.
“Nothing to worry about; he’s a lamb.”
Don Abbondio tried to climb into the saddle, with the chamberlain’s support. Up, up, up—and he was astride.
The sedan chair, borne by two more mules, was a few steps ahead of them. At the driver’s command it started to move, and the party was off.
They had to pass in front of the crowded church, crossing a square that was packed with villagers and travelers who hadn’t been able to get in.

The great news had already spread, and at the sight of the party, at the sight of that man, the object of hatred and terror only hours before, and now the object of joyful amazement, a murmur of approval arose from the crowd, which opened up before them and pushed forward at the same time to get a better look. The sedan chair passed by.

The Nameless One passed by. Before the open doors of the church, the nobleman doffed his hat and lowered his feared head all the way down to the mane of the mule, while a hundred voices whispered: “May God bless him!”

Don Abbondio also doffed his hat, bowed, and commended himself to heaven. But when he heard the solemn harmony of his confreres singing in chorus, he felt an envy, a rueful tenderness, and a heartache so deep he struggled to hold back his tears.
Once they were out of the village and into the open countryside, on winding and often deserted country roads, a darker veil settled over his thoughts.

Looking about for something or someone to trust, his gaze could only land upon the driver who, as a member of the Cardinal’s household, must be a good man, while also looking well-equipped to defend himself.

Every so often, other travelers would appear, alone or in groups, hurrying to see the Cardinal. Those moments were a relief for Don Abbondio, though only fleeting, since he was headed for that dreaded valley, where the only people he would encounter were his friend’s vassals: and what vassals they were!

Now more than ever, he would have preferred to start a conversation with his friend, to get a better sense of him and stay on his good side. But seeing the nobleman so preoccupied, he lost any desire to engage him, and thus was left to his own devices.
I will only give you a short sample of what the poor man said to himself on that trip, since to transcribe it all would require a book:

“Both saints and sinners have quicksilver in their veins: Truer words were never said. But while they’re in constant motion themselves, why do they have to drag the rest of us along? And who should the biggest busybody of all set his eyes upon and drag into this but me. Me! A man who minds his own business. Me! When all I want is to be left alone!
Then there’s that crazy troublemaker Don Rodrigo!
He could be the happiest man in the world if he had a lick of sense.
Rich, young, respected, courted: But no, the good life bores him, and he has to go digging up trouble for himself and everyone else.

He could be living the high life: But no, he chooses the most insane, rotten, and infuriating profession in the world: harassing women! He could go to heaven in a coach and six: But no, he’d rather limp his way to hell.

Not to mention that one…” And here he cast a sidelong glance at “that one,” as if suspecting the man could read his mind. “That one, after setting the world on fire with his crimes, is now setting it on fire with his conversion…If he really did convert!
Meanwhile I’m the one who gets stuck testing whether or not it’s true!…Nothing you can do about it: When they’re born with that fire in the belly, all they ever do is raise hell.
What’s so hard about living an honest life from childhood, like I have?
No, sir: You’d rather maim, murder, maraud. Poor me! And then all that hubbub about repentance. Repentance!
If you put your mind to it, you can repent in the peace and quiet of your own home, without fanfare, without bothering your neighbor.

And then His Grace, standing there with open arms at the drop of a hat: ‘My dear friend, my dear friend.’ To hear him carrying on, you’d think he’d witnessed a miracle. And then jumping headfirst into a decision, quickly quickly. Well, haste makes waste is what they say where I come from.
And then, to hand him over to a poor parish priest, with no precautions! Like flipping a coin to decide a man’s life.
A holy archbishop like him should be more protective of his priests, treat them like the apple of his eye.
It wouldn’t hurt his saintliness to practice a little self-control, a little prudence, a little charity, if you ask me…And what if the whole thing is an act?
Who knows what transpires in the hearts of men? Especially men like him!
And I’m the one that gets stuck accompanying him to his home!
Who knows what mischief is behind this: Poor me! Better not think about it!
And how did Lucia get mixed up in this mess?
Maybe there’s some kind of arrangement with Don Rodrigo. What terrible people! But at least it would explain things.
But how did that one get hold of her?
Who knows?
Everything’s so hush-hush with His Grace. And me, the one they send trotting off—nobody tells me anything.
I don’t want to know other people’s business—but if I’m risking my skin, I’ve got every right to know.
If all we’re doing is fetching that poor creature, so be it!
Although he could have brought her with him the first time.
And then, if he has converted, if he has become a holy father, what do they need me for?
What a mess!
Enough: I pray to God it’s true. It will have been a great bother, but all right.

I’ll be happy for poor Lucia’s sake: It must have been a narrow escape. God only knows what she went through. I feel sorry for her, but she’ll be the end of me…If I could only look into his heart and see what he’s thinking.
One minute he’s looking like Saint Anthony of the Desert; the next he’s Holofernes in the flesh.
Poor me! Poor me!
Never mind. Heaven help me, since I didn’t come here just for the fun of it.”

From the Nameless One’s face, one could, in fact, almost see the thoughts running through his head, the way the clouds pass over the sun in a storm, constantly alternating between an angry light and a cold darkness.

His spirit—still intoxicated by Federigo’s soothing words—felt remade and rejuvenated in this new life and ascended to thoughts of mercy, forgiveness, and love; then it fell back under the burden of his sinful past.

He reflected anxiously on which of his evil deeds he could repair, and which he could stop short of completing, and which remedies were the quickest and surest, and how to disentangle many knots, and what to do about so many accomplices: The mere thought of it all was staggering.

Even on the current expedition, which was the easiest and closest to completion, he proceeded with an impatient distress, worried about how much the poor girl was still suffering, and knowing that he, despite his eagerness to free her, was the cause of it.
When they came to a fork in the road, the driver turned around to ask directions: The Nameless One pointed the way with his hand, while at the same time gesturing him to hurry up.
They entered the valley.
Imagine how poor Don Abbondio felt in that moment!

To be inside that notorious valley, about which he’d heard such horrible stories. To see the flower of Italian bravi in the flesh and blood: notorious men, fearless and ruthless. To run into one, two, or three at every turn of the road.
They bowed submissively to the Nameless One, but what sunburnt faces! What thick mustaches! What nasty stares, which to Don Abbondio seemed to say, “Let’s rough up this priest.”

So great was his terror that, at its peak, he said to himself, “I wish I had married them! What could be worse than this!” All the while, they advanced along a rocky path beside the river: On the opposite side were harsh, dark, barren cliffs; on the near side, inhabitants that would make any wasteland preferable. He felt like Dante in the lower circles of hell!
They passed the Malanotte. Bravi at the door, bows to the lord, curious glances at his fellow traveler and the driver.
The men had no idea what to think. The Nameless One’s solitary departure that morning had already been extraordinary and his return now was no less so.
Was he leading his prey into a trap?
And how had he managed to snare them single-handedly?
And why the foreign sedan chair?
And whose livery was that?
They stared and stared, but not one of them moved, held back by their master’s forbidding glare.
They climb the slope. They’re at the top.

The bravi guarding the terrace and the gates step back and to the side to let them through. The Nameless One signals to them to stand still. He spurs his mule and passes in front of the sedan chair, signaling to the driver and to Don Abbondio to follow. He enters a first courtyard, then a second. He goes toward a small doorway, gestures “stay back” to a bravo who has run up to hold the stirrup, and tells him, “Stay here, and don’t let anyone in.”

He dismounts, quickly ties the mule to a railing, goes up to the woman in the sedan chair, who has drawn back the curtain, and whispers, “Try to comfort her immediately. Let her know immediately that she is free and among friends.
God will thank you for it!”

Then he gestures to the driver to open the sedan chair’s door. He turns to Don Abbondio and, with a more serene expression than the priest has ever seen or thought to see, flush with the joy of the good deed he is finally about to perform, whispers to him, “Father, I will not ask your forgiveness for the inconvenience to which I have subjected you. You are doing this for One who will repay you handsomely, and for this poor child of His.”
At this, he holds the bridle with one hand and the stirrup with the other, to help Don Abbondio dismount.
That face, those words, that gesture, restored the priest to life.
He let out a sigh of relief that had been building inside him for the last hour without finding a way out. He bowed toward the Nameless One and replied in a low, low voice, “Do you think so?
But, but, but…!” and slid off his mount as best he could.

The Nameless One tethered his mule and told the driver to wait. He took a key from his pocket, unlocked the door, and entered. He ushered in the priest and the woman, leading the way to a staircase, which all three ascended in silence.
